bug.short_desc: [hotbug] [modulecore] WebArtifactEdit needs to overwrite getAdapter()

long_desc.thetext: Requesting for this bug to go into the hotbug list for WTP 1.5.1. The problem prevents users from saving changes to web.xml if both editors are opened at same time.

ArtifactEdit has a constructor which can be used to solve this problem. Check out ArtifactEdit(IProject aProject, boolean toAccessAsReadOnly, boolean forCreate, String projectType). So, in your FooArtifactEdit you can expose an API to clients which will then make use of this constructor to get the edit model for that specific edit model ID.

I already use the ArtifactEdit constructor that provides the editModelID in the parameters. The problem is not there. The problem occurs when the WebEditor is opened and initializeValidateEditListener() is called, which calls the ArtifactEdit.getAdapter() (because WebArtifactEdit does not overwrite it). This results in calling ArtifactEditAdapterFactory.getAdapter(), which does the search based on the registered editModelIDs.
Since WebArtifactEdit knows its editModelID, it can avoid the call to ArtifactEditAdapterFactory.getAdapter() by overwriting the ArtifactEdit.getAdapter() method and always returning the correct ArtifactEditModel.

Ok, I see the problem. The problem is in the way the IBM editor is using the artifact edit generically to get the edit model. The artifact edit does get the proper edit model associated with it, but the API getAdapter() does not return the proper edit model.
Thanks. Updating the ArtifactEdit implementation is a much better solution. I tested it with my scenario and it fixed the problem.
Created an attachment (id=48411) Proposed patch

Attached patch, which has been tested by Aimee.
This is ready for review.
Approve
approve

Verified problem is resolved.

bug.short_desc: Fix unchecked conversions and use of raw types, where possible

assigned_to.name: Generic inbox for the JDT-APT component

long_desc.thetext:
The jdt.apt.core plug-in project is set to ignore warnings about unchecked conversion and use of raw types. This is because it has to translate between the JDT DOM API, which uses raw types, and the APT API, which uses generic types; so there are otherwise a lot of such warnings.
However, some of those warnings are legitimate; they're simply cases where the programmer forgot to use genericized types.
We should make a pass through the code with the warnings re-enabled, to clean up the sloppy cases.

All unchecked conversion and raw type related warnings have been either fixed or suppressed with @SuppressWarnings.
There are still some unrelated build warnings coming from recently deprecated extension point attributes. Fixing those is blocked on bug 155147. But that's not what this bug is about, so resolving as fixed.
Target milestone should be changed to 3.3 M2, but I don't have sufficient privileges to do so.

bug.short_desc: [import/export] J2EE Export Dialog default project selection wrong

long_desc.thetext: The various J2EE export dialogs do not correctly default the project selections. For example if there is an EJB and an EAR in the workspace and the EJB is selected in the Project Explorer and then the EAR export dialog is opened, the EJB project will be selected. The export dialogs should be smart enough to recognize that the EJB project is not valid and should not be selected. All J2EE export wizards exhibit this behavior. This should be pretty easy to fix because the export DataModels are already aware of the error. It should be a matter of checking if the project is in the list of valid values for the project property.

What if there are 1000 projects, 999 which are web, 1 which is ejb, and you select on the ejb and say export war? Would there be a noticeable delay to cycle through 999 applicable projects to see if the ejb was one of them? I notice the J2EEExportPages have a getComponentID() method. Can we just check the project type and see if it matches the expected componentID()? Or am I missing something?

I doubt there would be a delay. The 999 propert descriptors will be created when the combo is built anyway; I could add some caching there, but I don't think it will make any differenct to the user. The solution could be to set the wrong value, then validate it and see if it is correct; I don't like this either because it is bad style. There are other work arounds which involving more code, but considering how unlikely this scenario is, plus that this code is executing during a wizard creation and delay here is not unusual, I don't think the extra effor is justified.
Ok, fair enough. Approved.

When the object is loaded the server transmits all of the attributes, which include the super class attributes. The client side ignored the attributes and mis-interpreted the message containing the attributes as the next object. From this point on nothing will work...

Both client and server are current with CVS as of today.

What I saw in the logs looked very simple. It showed on the server that attributes from the super class were being returned, but the client did not expect the attributes for the super class. The client was mis-reading the attributes as more data from the server and then nothing worked.
I made the change on the client side and everything is working fine now. I will be including this change in my pending release.

bug.short_desc: Endpoints on curved arcs don't always attach to the source/target.

long_desc.thetext: On graphs using curved connections, the arcs won't always attach to the nodes where expected.

Created an attachment (id=48199) Fixes problem
The problem was due to precision errors when calculating arcs for large circles. This patch introduces a new class: PolylineArcConnection, which does the same math as the regular arc connection, but it interpolates the arc as a polyline rather than drawing it directly. This allows us to force the endpoints to be in the right position.
MidBendpointLocator has also been added to ensure that the labels on all polylines behve the same.
An experimental enhancement to the NestedGraphViewerImpl is added as well. In order to help keep context when navigating between nodes that aren't parents or children of the current focus node, the viewer now zooms out to the common parent of the two nodes that are being traversed, then zooms in on the new node.
Created an attachment (id=48200) mylar/context/zip
Patch is in head.
Now using PolylineArcConnections

bug.short_desc: Background loading with progress indication in task editor

long_desc.thetext: Currently, when you click on "Open" action from the task list it will run synchronize on that issue first and only then open the editor. The problem is that synchronize takes quite long time (20..30 seconds). So, it would be much better user experience if editor would be opened immediately, and bugzilla page stays empty while synchronizing.

Curretly tasks are opened immediately if there is local task data (has been opened/synced in past). If your offline reporst was lost the sync would take place first then the task would open, otherwise this should be working. Is there a condition I've overlooked?
I was browsing trough query hits. Those have no task data and I can't synchronize them up front without loosing "incoming" marker.

Yes, hits are a problem in that respect. We don't have all the data to give them a task data object up front. I think we're stuck with this unless we get the complete bug report for each hit which would be too expensive. I'm not sure opening with a blank bug editor would be all that intuitive. At least there is the syncing (italic) of the task name to indicate that some work is ongoing followed by opening of the editors.

I'd prefer to have an option to fetch all issue data up front (it is still being fetched as I open/browse those issues).
I think it is much better to open editor immediately and show progress bar in the bugzilla tab while it is loading. So, user won't have editors jumping out of nowhere after significant delay...
I see your point, renaming to reflect this idea. A progress indicator of some sort in the tab/page would be nice....

Note from my comments on bug 168432 that we don't yet have a clear guideline of whether the spinner should be on the form or on the editor tab. Also, here is what I would like to see for 2.0: 1) Open task editor: no background load, open is instant or close to instant since we are not going over the network. 2) Submit changes to server: editor stays open and shows progress indication when reloading input 3) Stale editor: reloads input in background when synch happens, and shows message in header to indicate to the user that the input has been re-loaded since their last viewing. The "incoming" indicator doesn't go away from the Task List until the editor has had focus and shown this message.

(In reply to comment #6) > 1) Open task editor: no background load, open is instant or close to instant > since we are not going over the network.
How about opening editor if there is no data? I believe think it should still instantly open a stub editor.
> 3) Stale editor: reloads input in background when synch happens, and shows > message in header to indicate to the user that the input has been re-loaded > since their last viewing. The "incoming" indicator doesn't go away from the > Task List until the editor has had focus and shown this message.
This is the most troblesome one. I think it is ok to remove incoming indicator as you suggesting, but then task should stay visible in the task list until editor is closed.

(In reply to comment #7) > How about opening editor if there is no data? I believe think it should still instantly open a stub editor.
I agree that this is better than locking up the workbench.
> This is the most troblesome one. I think it is ok to remove incoming indicator > as you suggesting, but then task should stay visible in the task list until > editor is closed.
Yes, this one will be tricky, and we should keep the "Stale Editor" dialog until we're sure that what we come up doesn't result in people accidentally missing incoming changes (very high cost).

(In reply to comment #8) > > How about opening editor if there is no data? I believe think it should still instantly open a stub editor. > I agree that this is better than locking up the workbench.
It is not about locking workbench. Right now if task data takes long time to fetch you'll see that editor jumping out of nowhere when you already forgot about it...
> > This is the most troblesome one. I think it is ok to remove incoming indicator > > as you suggesting, but then task should stay visible in the task list until > > editor is closed. > > Yes, this one will be tricky, and we should keep the "Stale Editor" dialog > until we're sure that what we come up doesn't result in people accidentally > missing incoming changes (very high cost).
I am not arguing the stale editor dialog. Though I'd prefer if we had some floating panel on the editor instead (similar to the search and warning panels in FireFox). also note that "stale editor" dialog does not have a cancel option.

bug.short_desc: [Dialogs] Javadoc - IconAndMessageDialog.createMessageArea assumes parent composite is using GridLayout

long_desc.thetext:
IconAndMessageDialog.createMessageArea assigns GridData objects as the layout data for the children of the parent composite. This mandates that the parent's layout is a GridLayout - which is unspecified in the Javadoc.
This affects all callers of IconAndMessageDialog.createMessageArea as well, for example: ErrorDialog.createDialogArea MessageDialog.createDialogArea ProgressDialog.createDialogArea

Assumptions about the use of grid data are pervasive in the dialog framework, and documented in some places better than others. For example, see the javadoc for Dialog.createDialogArea(Composite).
This could be documented better in the more specific methods such as createCustomArea, createMessageArea, etc.
marking for M7
Fixed in HEAD >20070407. Documented the assumption in createMessageArea.
verified by inspecting source, Win XP, I20070430-0800

bug.short_desc: [WorkingSets] Select Default Breakpoint Working Set dialog is confusing and can clear default setting accidentally

long_desc.thetext:
I have 2 breakpoing working set A and B. I do not have a default working set.
1. select A and set as default working set. 2. From the drop down menu of the Breakpoints View, use the "Select Default Working Set" action. This brings up the Select Working Set dialog.
From this dialog, select the "Selected Working Sets" radio button. I can select more than 1 working set from this dialog. If I select both working sets, does it mean that I have chosen both working sets as the default working sets? But I can only have one default working set at a time.
4. I got confused what I was doing, and selected both working sets. 5. Clicked OK.
My default working set setting is cleared. I do not have a default working set any more.
Expected behavior: User should not be allowed to select more than one working set when using this dialog if it is invoked from the "Select Default Working Set..." action.

This seems to be happening because the working set dialogs are being allowed to close when more than one working set is selected. We are using Platform UI's working set dialogs, which are spec'd to not allow the dialog to close if more than one working set is selected (when passed false in the multi parameter).
Kicking over to platform UI for comment...

The dialog still honours multi, only the meaning is slightly different. If multi is false, then the result of selecting multiple working sets in the dialog is an aggregate working set made up of the components - only one set is returned. In no case are multiple working sets returned.
I've done a quick look at the debug code and it looks like you're making some assumptions about what is returned from the dialog. You're doing work based on the ID of the returned working set, assuming it'll be of type Debug working set. This is not the case, however, when an aggregate is returned - aggregates have a null value for getId().
You should ensure that your code honours the aggregate working set APIs introduced in 3.2. From our perspective we're honouring the working set dialog javadoc.

fixed in HEAD
instead of working with aggregates, we provide a selection dialog that allow users to simply and quickly select what they want to be the new default working set.
see SelectBreakpointWorkingsetDialog
please verify Darin W
Verified, with minor NLS update.
